Ponec Corlaeus Laboratories, Leiden Institute of Chemistry, P O Box 9502, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands Received 21 September 1993, revised 13 June 1994, accepted 21 June 1994 Abstract The activity of vanous 3d, 4d and 5d transition metal oxides to the selective reduction of nitrobenzene to nttrosobenzene has been investigated An attempt has been made to find a correlation between these activities and several properties of the oxides investigated, such as their place to the Penodtc Table, structure, reducibility, heat of formation and surface metal-oxygen bond strength A weak volcano-shape correlation can be seen with the heat of formation and the surface metal-oxygen bond strength Keywords Bond strength, Metal-oxygen bond, Nitrobenzene, Selective reduction, Transition metal oxides 1. Introduction The catalytic activity and selectivity of metal oxides depend on several factors Various authors relate the catalytic activity to the formation enthalpy of the metal oxide as a measure for the strength of the metal-oxygen bond [ 1-3 ] However, in most cases the bulk average thermochemical properties, like the heat of formation, cannot charactense the bond strength of surface oxygen in particular bonds Therefore, in other papers the activity is related to the properties like the rate of the isotopic oxygen exchange [ 4 ] , the amount of excess oxygen [ 5 ] , the heat of desorption of oxygen from the surface [ 6,7,24,25 ] , the calculated metal oxygen bond strength [ 8 ] or calculated metal-oxygen bond energy [ 9,10] According to Sachtler et al [ 11 ] , the catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of benzaldehyde increases when the metal-oxygen bond strength decreases, whereby successive removal of a second and third oxygen atom from around a certain cation would * Corresponding author 0304-5102/94/$07 00 1994 Elsevier Science B V All rights reserved SSDI0304-5102(94)00121-9 306 A Maltha et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 305-316 require considerably more energy than removal of the first oxygen atom and this factor dictates the ratio selective/deep oxidation The catalytic activity can also be related to other factors, like undersaturation of the surface atoms [ 7,12,13 ] , the acidity of the surface [ 14], the kind of crystallographic plane that is preferentially exposed (this seems to be particularly important for the selectivity of the reaction) [ 7,9,10,12 ] or the structure of the surface (stenc hindrance, heterogeneity) Of course, many of these factors are influenced by the mode of preparation of the corresponding metal oxide and the surrounding atmosphere The relationship between the above mentioned properties of transition metal oxides and their catalytic activities have been extensively studied m (selective) oxidation reactions, thus m reactions where the oxide surface is partially reduced by one component of the reaction, whereafter the oxygen vacancies are replenished by di-oxygen However, the second step can also be used to advantage, for example for a selective reduction reaction, like the selective reduction of nitrobenzene to mtrosobenzene [ 15 ] Not much research has been done yet on the relationship between transition metal oxides and their properties on one side and the behaviour m selective reduction reactions on the other side The oxide Mn304 is a good catalyst for the selective reduction (see Eq 1) of nitrobenzene [ 15 ] , ON02 + H2- ONO + H20 (l' ) ON02 + CO - ONO + C02 (1") 27ON02 -j 25ON0+ 12C02 +5H20 (1"') "autoreduction" but it appeared from exploratory experiments that other 3d transition metal oxides also showed good activity [ 16 ] The differences m the activities of the 3d transition metal oxides m the selective reduction of nitrobenzene were much smaller than those m, for example, the oxidation of hydrogen, see Fig 1 [ 17,18 ] (note the difference with the figure m [ 18 ] , because m that paper, the catalytic activity for the selective reduction of nitrobenzene has been expressed m "mol") The smaller activity differences are probably due to a different kind of reoxidation step m the case of the oxidation reaction two oxygens should enter the lattice, whereas m the case of the selective reduction reaction, only one oxygen should enter the lattice at once since selective reduction of nitrobenzene to mtrosobenzene removes only one oxygen from the molecule The main side reaction, in reactions with an external reducer, is the aniline production e g according to ON02 + 3H2 - ONH2 + 2H2 O (2 ) upon which reaction two oxygen atoms have to be removed. Experimental 2 I Preparation of the catalysts The oxides described in this paper are oxides with the formulae AB204 (splnel), M203, M03, M205 and M02 The following oxides were commercial samples T102 (Ventron, Karlsruhe), Zr02 (Merck, Darmstadt), Nb205 (Fluka AG, Buchs SG), Ta205 (Fluka AG, Buchs SG) and Hf02 V205 was made by calcination of NH4V03 at 673 K for 20 h [ 19] V203 was made by reduction of V205 at 673 K M003 was prepared by calcination of (NH4)6Mo7024 at 873 K for 17 h W03 was synthesised by precipitation of Na2W04 ZH20 with 15 M HN03 Mn304, ZnMn204, Co304, ZnC0204, ZnCr204 and Fe203 were prepared from hydroxides, obtained by precipitation of the corresponding metal nitrates at pH = 9 The hydroxides were decomposed in air at 400 K Co304 and ZnC0204 were moreover calcined at 873 K, ZnCr204 was calcined at 1073 K [ 20] and Fe203 was calcined at 600 K Mn203 was made by oxidation of Mn304 at 573 K for 1 5 h in a flow of pure oxygen Fe304 was prepared by reduction of Fe203 at 573 K for 1 5 h in a flow of pure hydrogen [ 21 ] The following oxides were synthesised by the decomposition of the corresponding metal nitrates in air Cr203 (673 K, 4 h), Ni0 (673 K, 20 h), Cu0 (600 K, 20 h), Zn0 (700 K, 20 h), ZnFe204 (873 K, 20 h, then 1273 K, 20 h, then 1473 K, 20 h) and La203 (1123 K, 17 h) [ 22 ] 308 A Maltha et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 305-316 2 2 Catalyst characterisation All catalysts were analysed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) Surface area measurements were performed on a Quantasorb apparatus from Quantachrome The simplest one point method was used Thermogravimetnc experiments were done on a Setaram thermobalance A flow of 5% Hz/Ar with a flow rate of 100 ml/mm was used The temperature was increased from 300 K to 1100 K with 5 K/ mm 2 3 Catalytic data measurements and evaluation Catalytic measurements were carried out m an open flow system with fixed bed reactor Products were analysed with a GC. The reaction conditions were, standard temperature of the reaction was 573 K, carrier gas was helium, pressure of nitrobenzene was 70 Pa (total pressure was 1 bar) and the flow rate was 25 ml/mm The reaction was performed without an extra reducer (autoredox) or with an extra reducer (CO) Analysis was performed on-line with a GC, using an automatically driven sampling valve For more details see [ 15 ] 3. Discussion It can be concluded from the above described experiments, that nearly all 3d, 4d and 5d transition metal oxides are active in the selective reduction of nitrobenzene Experiments with other metal oxides, like Sn02, B1203, PbO, Ce02 and A1203 [ 26,27 ] , show that not only transition metal oxides are active, but that the activity is obviously due to the fact that a metal ion can change its valency during the reaction A certain M" + /M" + 1 ratio in the surface layers of the oxide is necessary, as can be seen with Mn203 that is partially reduced by the running reaction to Mn304, while MnO is partially oxidised to Mn304 [ 15 ] In a similar manner, V203 when used was oxidised to V204 and V205 was partially reduced to V409 Addition of CO as an external reducer renders in most cases a strong decrease in the selectivity and in the apparent activation energy Without CO, oxygen vacancies are created by oxidation of the phenyl ring of nitrobenzene When CO is added to the feed, A Maltha et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 305-316 315 these vacancies are created mainly by CO When aniline is being simultaneously produced by the autoreduction, or with CO as the reducer, then the hydrogenation proceeds by the surface OH groups, which are supplied by hydrogen from the phenyl ring fragments [ 29 ] The whole picture of the rate as a function of temperature indicates a creation by CO of a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies at low temperatures, i e , under conditions that the reduction of the surface by the phenyl group is slow 'Some oxides do not show a decrease in the selectivity, when CO is added to the feed This is due to the high-temperature synthesis of the oxides there are no (or only a few) hydroxyl groups on the surface of these oxides, groups which are needed for aniline formation [ 29 ] Some correlation can be found between the heat of formation of the oxides and their activity in the selective reduction of nitrobenzene This volcano-shaped correlation would mean that there is an optimum metal-oxygen bond strength Moreover, the bond strength in the bulk of the oxides should in this case represent the bond strength at the surface However, another explanation for the higher activity of some oxides (Mn304, Mn203, Vz05 and W03) is also possible the spinel Mn304 is tetragonally distorted, thus the distance of two of the six metal-oxygen bonds, when manganese is in octahedral position, is larger This means that some of the bonds in Mn304 are weaker than the average metal-oxygen bond XRD results showed that Mn203 is by the reaction partially converted into Mn304, thus this catalyst has probably also more reactive oxygen The surface of VZ05 has been converted to V409, which can have more of reactive oxygen than other oxides For example, literature data [ 28 ] show that the (001) plane of V6013 would expose about twice as many V=O bonds on V6013 than the (010) plane on V205 Some of the V=O bonds on V6013 are more undersaturated than those on V205 and can be expected to be more active in oxidation and ammoxidation reactions The fact that the catalyst W03 is more active than the other 4d and 5d oxides can also be due to the fact that there is more reactive oxygen at the surface of this oxide, because this catalyst has been synthesised at lower temperatures than the other ones The poor correlation between the activity of the various oxides and the activation energy of oxygen desorption also shows that the activity in the selective reduction reaction does not only depend on the metal-oxygen bond strength (at least not on these experimentally determined bond strengths), but also on factors as mentioned above It seems probable that the metal-oxygen bond strengths on the surface of the oxides depend on the preparation method, as mentioned above It seems that synthesis of oxides at high temperatures removes most of the reactive oxygen 5. Conclusion Most transition metal oxides, which can change valency, are active in the selective reduction of nitrobenzene to nitrosobenzene The activity is rather sensitive to the preparation method and to individual metal-oxygen bonds on the surface of the 316 A Maltha et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 305-316 oxides There is no clear correlation with the place of the metal element The activity of various 3d, 4d and 5d transition metal oxides in the selective reduction of nitrobenzene to nitrosobenzene has been investigated. An attempt has been made to find a correlation between these activities and several properties of the oxides investigated, such as their place in the Periodic Table, structure, reducibility, heat of formation and surface metal—oxygen bond strength. A weak volcano-shape correlation can be seen with the heat of formation and the surface metal—oxygen bond strength. coredata.dc:description: The activity of various 3d, 4d and 5d transition metal oxides in the selective reduction of nitrobenzene to nitrosobenzene has been investigated. An attempt has been made to find a correlation between these activities and several properties of the oxides investigated, such as their place in the Periodic Table, structure, reducibility, heat of formation and surface metal—oxygen bond strength. A weak volcano-shape correlation can be seen with the heat of formation and the surface metal—oxygen bond strength.
coredata.dc:title: Transition metal oxides as catalysts for the selective reduction of nitrobenzene
